supportDesc.support: A manuscript of four separate parts, each consisting of paper leaves.

foliation.p: This catalogue record contains several early modern and modern foliation and pagination sequences. These are each described in turn below as Foliation Sequences 1-3. In order to produce a useable sequence for the present digital catalogue record (for which unique folio numbers are required), some of these sequences are followed (wholly or in part), while others are ignored. The prefatory numbers (i.e. '1:', '2:', etc) refer not to the relevant Foliation Sequence, however, but to the Part of the manuscript in which they are found.

The resulting, amalgamated foliation sequence is as follows: [i]-[ii] + 1:1-1:57, [1:57a], 1:58-1:59 [cf. Foliation Sequence 2 below] | 2:i-2:iv, [2:v] [cf. Foliation Sequence 2 below], 2:1-2:32 [cf. Foliation Sequence 3 below], 2:33 [not written out in any sequence but implied], 2:34-2:68 [cf. Foliation Sequence 2 below], 2:69 [cf. Foliation Sequence 3 below], 2:70-2:71 [cf. Foliation Sequence 2 below] | 3:129, [3:129a], 3:130-3:135 [cf. Foliation Sequence 1 below], 3:i-3:viii [cf. Foliation Sequence 2 below], 3:136-3:187, 3:187a, 3:188-3:196, [3:196a], 3:197-3:207, [3:207a], 3:208-3:210, [3:210a], 3:211-3:215, 3:215a, 3:216-3:224, 3:224a, 3:225-3:226, 3:226a-3:226b, 3:227-3:242, 3:242a [cf. Foliation Sequence 1 below] | 4:243-3:266, 4:266a, 4:267-4:269 [cf. Foliation Sequence 1 below] + [iii]-[iv]

Folios [i]-[ii] and [iii]-[iv] are unfoliated early modern paper flyleaves at the beginning and end of the manuscript that have been allocated Roman numerals between square brackets for reference purposes in this electronic catalogue record.
Sequence 1: 17th- or 18th-century continous foliation throughout Parts 1, 2, 3, and 4:
foliation.note: Numbering in dark ink in the upper left-hand and right-hand corners or centre of the upper margins of the rectos. The numbers '51'-'82' have been largely crossed out, although some have been partly crossed so that remaining numbers could be reused for a new foliation sequence (see below)

note.p: Folio [129a] is an unfoliated stub with (some) writing and ff. [196a], [207a], and [210a] are unfoliated fragments of leaves with writing that have been allocated a number between square brackets for reference purposes in this electronic catalogue record.
This foliation is supplemented in pencil by a modern hand: letters a and b for duplicate numbers, and numbers and letters for unfoliated pages: 187a, 242a, 266a, 268, and 269.
This foliation sequence is partially followed in this catalogue record, which ignores it for Parts 1 and 2, but follows it (with its modern supplements) for Parts 3 and 4.

foliation.p: Sequence 2: 20th-century foliation in sections of Parts 1, 2, and 3:
foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand and left-hand corners of the rectos.

Folio [57a] is an unfoliated paper stub with (some) writing on it and f. [1:v] is a blank unfoliated leaf that have been allocated numbers between square brackets for reference purposes in this electronic catalogue record.
foliation.p: This foliation sequence is entirely followed in this catalogued record.

foliation.note: Numbering in dark ink in the upper left-hand corner of the rectos. The foliator has created the numbers '1'-'9' by crossing out part of the 17th-century foliation sequence that is continuous for Parts 1-4 (see above).

The numbers '60'-'68' have been crossed out by the 17th-century continuous foliator (see above) and the modern foliator (see above), although the latter seem to have accepted and integrated its number '69' (f. 2:69) into their sequence.
This foliation sequence is partially followed in this catalogue record: it follows the number sequence '1'-'32', and '69'.

collation.p: Due to the complexity of this manuscript and tightness of the current biding, it has not been possible to propose a plausible collation for Parts 1, 2, and 3. The collation summary below is for Part 4 only.

note.p: This catalogue record deviates from the collation provided by M.R. James (1902), which is followed by Mooney (1995) and Timmermann (2015), in that it does not divide the manuscript into three parts but identifies four separate parts. It also suggests that Part 3 may consist of further parts. However, due to the tightness of the current binding it has not been possible to securely identify their ranges.

binding.p: (?)17th-century binding of brown leather; the spine re-backed with three paper labels containing the separate alpha-numerical elements of the manuscript's classmark: O, 1, 65.

provenance.p: One of the manuscripts of Thomas Gale (1635/6-1702) Gale, Thomas, 1635/6-1702, dean of York, antiquary and fellow of Trinity College Cambridge.
One of the manuscripts of Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, antiquary and scholar, son of Thomas Gale. Inherited from his father.

acquisition.p: Donated to Trinity College by Roger Gale (1672-1744)Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, son of Thomas Gale (1635/6-1702), in 1738. The alpha-numerical elements of its classmark are printed on three paper tabs on the damaged spine: O, 1, 65. The classmark O.1.65 inscribed in red ink on the inside of the front cover and in brown ink on f. 1:1r. The College's ex libris, featuring its armorial coat of arms, motto (Virtus Vera Nobilitas), name (Coll: Trin: Cantab:), and portrait of King Henry VIII, engraved by William Stephens, fl. c. 1740-c. 1760 (W. Stephens sculp.) is pasted on the inside of the front cover; another simpler ex libris, also engraved by William Stephens, is pasted on f. 1:1v. The College's bookstamp occurs on f. 1:1r and f. 1:269v

msItem.title: Accounts about miraculous creatures seen in Southern France
msItem.incipit: 1:55v-1:56r [...]ost at midnight about .1[?1]. years since a fiery dragon flying close by him as he stood on a monteyne, which had two piked eares the mouth open flaming with fier the eyes al fiery, and great winges making with his wing[es] a great brut before he came at them . it had two leggs which it claped close to the belly It came from the mountayne of Baux with many dead lakes and inhabitable plenes and rocky caves [...] and it flewe over the place Pugeol and descended into a forest caled mou[...] it had the tayle al in a knot. At Bederide herd by a vegneor [? vigneron] he was at the killing of a huge adder as big as my thye about .8. speces long, which killed the doges and resisted the strookes of the ?heraguet[...] but at last he was killed and it raging at the point of death pust forth such venoumes vapours that .3. or .4 died incontinent after. By Bayon a cruell serpent was killed that was engendred in an old ruinous castell . it had 3 heades and euery head cast forth such abondance of fier that it burne al that cam[e] agaynst it to combat it : at last it was kil[led] In Bayon in the chef church it is yet to [be] seen. In Pugeol lack a great eele taken and sould in Auignion, the serpent [...] and coniunction dayly with this eel was enraged to mis hir comagnion, swom vp and downe the pond in a rage for .3. days space hissing and raginge . The eele was sould to cardinal armoniac and if the fisherman had not come to aduertise the master of the castel, that he feared that it was the compagnion of the serpent, the cardinal had ben possoned, for it being ready betwen two dishes to be served in, by the cardina[ls] commandment it was cast to a dog which eatinge it swelled incontinent and died. The serpent was as great as the eel, whom the fishermen took raging in the lake in a net and kiled it.
msItem.note: Full transcription. Four accounts about monstrous creatures as told by eye-witnesses to the author (who is probably also the scribe). According to Timmermann (2015), these accounts are alchemical allegories. The first account tells about a winged dragon from the mountain of Baux, perhaps Les-Baux-de-Provence, that was seen flying over Pugeol, perhaps Pujols, Southwestern France. The second account is about a huge adder at Bederide, probably Bedarrides near Avignon in Southeastern France. The third account is about a three-headed serpent that was killed at a castle at Bayon, perhaps Bayonne in Southwestern France. The fourth and final account tells about a great eel and his serpent compagnon and is partly set in Avignon, Southeastern France, referring to a cardinal Armoniac, perhaps Georges d'Armagnac (b. c. 1501, d. 1585), who was appointed cardinal in 1544.

note.p:
This collection of medical recipes is largely written in French but also features recipes in Italian, Latin, and English. It contains various references to locations and alchemical and medical practitioners:
Nymes [Nîmes, Southeastern France] (f. 2:1r)
Puluis domini d'Ampvilij (iam grand canestable de France) [probably referring to Henri de Montmorency (1534-1614)), 3rd Duke of Montmorency, Seigneur of Damville, Governer of Languedoc, who was Constable of France between 1593 and 1614] (f. 2:1v)
Verole - Mal de Naples (f. 2:2v)
morbum Neapolitanum (ff. 2:5r)
Dus Castel. [also abbreviated as Castell.] (ff. 2:18r, 2:18v, 2:19r, 2:21r, 2:22r, 2:22v [2x], 2:24r, 2:24v, 2:26r, 2:27r, 2:27v [crossed out], 2:33r, 2:37v, 2:42r)
le cheveux ou Barb. [...] est venu de Aleppo du Levant (f. 2:18r)
Mr de la Pierre or Dominus de la Pierre (ff. 2:18r, 2:27v, 2:37r, 2:43v, 2:44r, 2:44v, 2:45r, 2:46r, 2:46v [2x], 2:47r [2x], 2:48v, 2:49v, 2:50r, 2:50v [2x], 2:51r, 2:52r)
Mr de Castlemount or Dominus de Castelmont, often abbreviated to Ds Castel. (ff. 2:21r, 2:22r, 2:37r, 2:37v, 2:42r, 2:44r, 2:44v, 2:45r, 2:46r, 2:46v [2x], 2:47r [2x], 2:48v, 2:49v, 2:50r, 2:50v [2x], 2:51r)
Mr Renauld (f. 2:21r)
Hb (f. 2:25r)
Ds Chamb: (f. 2:27r, 2:27v, 2:34r [2x], 2:34v, 2:35r, 2:45r)
Pomatum domini Petri (f. 2:36v); Mr Lunelli (f. 2:43r)
Mr Sceic (f. 2:43v)
Mr Danuge [Daunge] (f. 2:43r)
Augustin Maulnoyr [or Mauluoyr de Romorantin de Sologne (f. 2:52r) [the name Maulnoyr or Mauluoyr also occurs on f. 2:58v]
Hollerius [most likely referring to Jacques Houllier (b. ?1504, d. 1562), known as Jacobus Hollerius Stampani, Professor of Medicine at the University of Paris] (f. 2:63v)

On f. 2:4r is an account about a medicine used at an unidentified monastery: Hoc expe[ri]mento monachus nutriuit totum conventum in [crossed out: Al] A[...] cum quo mirabilia fecit, et quando nimia confectus [...]it aetate vendidit tribus sacerdotibus de suo convent[o] pro decem aureis.

Some of the recipes feature titles and words that are written in a cypher. In the usual encryption method, vowels have been replaced for their preceding or successive letters in the alphabet (e.g. opxr ifs fscrpfs - jf xngxfnt [=pour les escroet - le unguent] on f. 2:7r); and Dfs fscrpfis encancarides [=Des escrofit encancarides] on f. 2:8v). In another encryption method, vowels have been replaced with the letter q where the number of horizontal strokes through its descender represents the numerical value of a vowel (e.g. [q2]mpl[q1]str[q2] p[q4][q5]r t[q4][q5]t[q4]s [q5][q4][q2]g[...] vlceros [=emplastre pour toutos voeg[...] ulceros] on f. 2:14r). In a third and more unusual encryption method, both consonants and vowels appear to have been scrambled with their preceding and/or successive letters in the alphabet, and a selection of letters has been replaced with symbols. This cypher, which can be found on f. 2:12r of this manuscript but also occurs in Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.1.13 (see ff. 84r, 120v, 121r).
The recipes are accompanied by a drawing of a flask in brown ink on f. 2:33r; and several alchemical vessels in brown ink on ff. 2:64r-2:64v.

note.p: The recipes feature various encrypted words in their titles and lists of ingredients, e.g. Mpdxs cpnfkckfdk zxcbrxm cbndk. R. zxto rxm blbkssksskmx et dxrxm et clbrkfkcb [etc.] [=Modus conficiendi zucarum candidissimum Recipe zucarum albassissimum et durum et clorifica] (f. 3:141v). msItem.note: Full transcription. Probably added by a la 15th- or early 16th-century hand. According to J.W. Horsley, Place Names in Kent (Maidstone: 'South Eastern Gazette' Newspaper, 1921), the placename Shepherdswell is a corruption of Sibertswalt, first recorded in the Domesday Book. msItem.title: Collection of medical and alchemical recipes

note.p: The collection includes instrucions for treating corrupted wine on f. 3:176r, and a recipe entitled confeccio sanguinis veneris, requiring the blood of a young woman who is a virgin, on f. 3:179r-3:179v. This recipe, as well as the Emplastrum quod vocatur Neyrbon sic fiet on ff. 3:180r-3:180v may have been extracted from John Arderne's Practica of fistula in ano [see his Pulvis sanguis veneris].
Some of the recipes have encrypted titles, e.g. Bprbczs pulcrvm (f. 3:174r).

Several of the recipes in this collection are associated with medical practitioners:
Pro Gomorria secundum M W. Castelle (f. 3:172v)
Pro Vlceracione Reins faict per Apultrewyk per M. W. Castell (f. 3:173r)
Vnguentum Terbentius secundum ffratrem W. Holm (f. 3:177v)
Contra [...] Pro Thoma lopham (f. 3:177v)
Emplastrum pro Lumbis rembz per R. K. (f. 3:183r)
Emplastrum pro Epate secundum W. Holm (f. 3:183v)
Pro calculo et pro stranguria per S. Robert ffille Capell secundum M. (f. 3:184v)

None of the aforementioned practitioners have been identified, except for frater W. Holm who must be the Franciscan friar William Holme (fl. c. 1380-1415) whose recipes are frequently cited in the Tabula medicine and who compiled two medical works (see Peter Murray Jones The Medicine of the Friars in Medieval England, Health and Healing in the Middle Ages, 5 (Woodbridge: Boydell and Brewer, 2024), pp. 74-96).
